NORMAN THOMAS IS
HEARD BY LIBERALS
Socialist is First Speaker at
Liberal Conference
SUBJECT IS "POWER"
Cites Failure of Regulation of
Public Utilities
Regulation of public utilities is
not an adequate solution of the
power problem, Norman Thomas,
formerly candidate of the Socialist
party for President and for Mayor
of New York, told the delegates to
the second annual Intercollegiate
Liberal Conference at the opening
session in Levering Hall Friday
night. The conference was sponsored by the Liberal Club of the
University and dealt with the question "The Socialization of Power."
Mr. Thomas was advertised to
debate on the subject "Shall Our
Power Resources Be Socialized?"
but the committee, according to
Joel Seidman, although it tried for
three months, was unable to secure
an opponent for the Socialist leader.
Both Seidman and Mr. Thomas said
they believed the failure to secure
an opponent was significant of the
unwillingness of the power interests, who were asked to send a
speaker, to discuss the situation.

HOPKINS SENIORS TO
VOTE FOR ANNUAL
questionnaires
Hullabaloo
were distributed to seniors at
the University, last Friday.
The questionnaires are part of
the annual program followed
by the staff of the campus annual.
One section of the book is
devoted to relating the failings
or accomplishments of those
students who have spent their
share of years at Homewood.
Such important facts as "Who
is the best dresser," "the handsomest," "the smothest," and
"the most virtuous" will be
subject to consideration on the
part of prospective candidates
for graduation.
Seniors are asked to fill out
these questionnaires and return
them as soon as possible.

Wolfe And Nixdorf Tally
For Olympics
In a game that was marked by a
great deal of clever and crafty playing, the Johns Hopkins Varsity
twelve downed the Olympic Club
stickmen last Saturday afternoon at
Homewood field in the opening
game of the season.
Veterans Crafty

The veteran team, which represented the United States at Amsterdam in 1928 in the Olympic Games,
was in much better physical condition last Saturday than they were
last spring when they met the Varsity twelve in their opening game.
This improvement on the physical
side, did play a part in helping the
veterans to keep the issue in doubt
right up until the final whistle blew,
but it was their great experience in
the art of the game and their alertness, what was the main factor in
making it possible for them to keep
the Varsity on the run.

In addressing a banquet of the
Alumni Association of Washington
College, Governor Ritchie pointed
out that the "recognition of the
smaller colleges of Maryland as
integral parts of the higher educational system of the State is an ideal
policy to pursue in the future."
Governor Ritchie views with consternation the universities in other
sections of the country which have
enrollment of from 20,000 to 40,000
students; he finds it impossible to
conceive that proper or competent
instruction can be carried out in
such large institutions. A program
of decentralization, according to
Dr. Paul E. Titsworth, who also addressed the gathering would aid the
educational process, which he defined as one of "contact of the immature mind with the mature and
mellowed intellect."

EDITORIALS
TOO BAD
HE movement on foot to revive varsity baseball at Hopkins is a

Tworthy one, but one that is fore-doomed to failure. Baseball is an

excellent game to play and, while .lacking the speed of lacrosse, is an
interesting sport to watch, particularly if the spectators are conversant
with the intricacies of the game. The sports writers of the country,
in a recent poll, praised baseball as the game most fitted for college
men. They claimed that the game is fine exercise for all the muscles
of the body and that it does not exert the tremendous physical and
nervous strain upon the player that lacrosse and football do.
Nevertheless, we feel that the athletic authorities will never consent
to a baseball team at Hopkins. From their point of view, they are
right, for baseball is a game that requires a great deal of financial outlay without drawing large enough crowds to compensate for the expense involved.. Furthermore, the undergraduate body at Hopkins is
too small to furnish enough material for both good lacrosse and baseball teams. Even if there were enough material, the lure of the diamond would coax many men from the crease just as track now claims
men who are potential lacrosse stars. And the athletic authorities will
do nothing to dim the wonderful reputation which Hopkins has now
in lacrosse.
So the baseball enthusiasts must resign themselves to failure, worthy
as their cause is. It is a great pity that our athletic appropriation is
, . not large enough to increase the variety of teams representing Hopkins.

MORE CONGRATULATIONS
Hopkins students were given a big boost toward success
SIXTEEN
in their chosen profession when they were admitted to the Medical
School last week. These students can claim without fear of contradiction that their college years have been successful.
The start in life which the Hopkins Medical School gives its graduates is equalled by no other educational institution in the country. It
surpasses its nearest rival, the Harvard School of Law, in the universal
esteem with which it endows its graduates. A man is not made simply
because he has received his M. D. from Hopkins, but, other things
being equal, he has a great advantage over his fellows at the start.
Particularly so if he intends to practice in Baltimore or the vicinity.
The reputation of the Medical School works only one evil; it
overshadows the other departments of the University. Because the
Medical School is so well known, laymen throughout the country believe that all Hopkins men are students of medicine or are, at least,
pursuing a pre-medical course. However, all Hopkins men puff with
pride at the mention of the Medical School even though they must
constantly explain that there really are other departments to the University.
Once more we congratulate the students who have been admitted
to the Medical School with the wish that they take full advantage of
the opportunity offered them.

The California Daily Bruin carries an interesting clipping concerning a novelty at the University of
Nevada: "Not since the days of
forty-niners in Nevada has there
been such a revival of the red-blooded, old-fashioned pastime of growing whiskers as that to be witnessed
on the chins of the students of the
State University here. The occasion
for all the hirsute display is the renewal of the traditional "whiskerins" dance festival of the University of Nevada, with every instructor, professor and student present
and 'bearded like the paro.'"

The Carnegie Institute of Technology at Pittsburgh, will hold its
annual exhibition, during which all
departments of the various colleges
will be open for public inspection.
With the characteristic attention of
the present day to the field of aviation, the exhibition will be featured
by an air tunnel, where, under the
direction of Mr. Lane Johnson, various aeroplane tests and aeronautical experiments will be conducted.
In addition to the specialty, there
will be a series of tests of model
dams by the Materials and Hydraulic Research Laboratories department; an advertising exhibition,
a retreat parade by the R. 0. T. C.,
and an exhibition of an Italian village square made entirely by students will, according to figures
made at the last exhibition, attract
some 12,000 visitors. Additional features on the program will include
music recitals, plays, concerts, exhibitions by members of the varsity swimming team and displays of
the work of students in the various
departments.

Another once well-accepted tradition gone the way of all flesh: In
the spring a young man's fancy
does not turn to thoughts of love
—a compilation of statistics by the
faculty at the Pennsylvania State
College shows that at this season of
the year, contrary to general opinion as the morbid effects of spring
fever, the . college student applies
himself more diligently in his work
and takes a more interested part in
campus activities than at any other
period of the term.

In the College of Law at the
Ohio State University, excuses
claiming sickness as a reason for
absence will no longer be accepted
unless the student has suffered from
a "protracted illness." A student
who has "cut" more than 15 per
cent of his classes will be barred
from taking examination, and will
be failed automatically, as a part of
a program of attendance enforcement, announced by Dean Hershel
W. Arant. The ruling aims principally at "fake" excuses; "many excuses offered," asserted Dean Arant,
"are not for valid illness, yet we
cannot take time to investigate the
genuineness of every case." The 15
per cent privilege, the dean believes,
will allow the student ample leeway
for slight illnesses, absences due to
business of other reasons. Hereafter, every excuse will be required
to have the personal approval of the
dean.

According to an announcement
ma de by Laurie D. Cox, a noted author on lacrosse, the University of
Maryland has placed two men on
the All-American lacrosse team and
has also achieved second ranking
among lacrosse teams of the country. The two old-timers to gain this
distinction are Bill Evans in home,
and Emmet Loane, second defense.
Evans, who is still with the Maryland team was also the highest point
scorere of the country last year.

0. D. K. ANNOUNCES
INITIATION DATE
Omicron Delta Kappa will
initiate new members on
Thursday, May 1, instead of
April 10, as was formerly announced. 0. D. K. is a national honorary organization and
admission to that group has
for several years been considered on the Hopkins campus
the highest honor that is attainable.
This body bases its qualifica- tions for membership on extracurricular activities, only those
being recognized as leaders in
their respective branches being
chosen. The spring election
will be the second held during
the college year, and differs
from the fall elections in that
juniors as well as seniors are
eligible for selection.

Last Saturday, Professor Albright, of the Department of Semetic Languages in Hopkins, addressed the Baltimore Quarterly
Meeting, in the Friends Meeting
Hall, on Charles Street. He spoke
on "Archaeological Explanation in
the Land of the Bible," and used
slides to show the interesting remains.

Plans are being made to professionalize the Federal prison service
by enlisting high-grade officers and
by establishing a system of professional training and promotion on
merit. In the belief that collegetrained men may be interested in
this type of work the leading colleges and universities in the country
are being circularized. Any undergraduate or graduate who wishes to
consider the possibility of entering
the service is requested to write the
Superintendent of Prisons, Department of Justice, Washington, D. C.

NORMAN THOMAS IS
HEARD BY LIBERALS
Socialist is First Speaker at
Liberal Conference
SUBJECT IS "POWER"
Cites Failure of Regulation of
Public Utilities
Regulation of public utilities is
not an adequate solution of the
power problem, Norman Thomas,
formerly candidate of the Socialist
party for President and for Mayor
of New York, told the delegates to
the second annual Intercollegiate
Liberal Conference at the opening
session in Levering Hall Friday
night. The conference was sponsored by the Liberal Club of the
University and dealt with the question "The Socialization of Power."
Mr. Thomas was advertised to
debate on the subject "Shall Our
Power Resources Be Socialized?"
but the committee, according to
Joel Seidman, although it tried for
three months, was unable to secure
an opponent for the Socialist leader.
Both Seidman and Mr. Thomas said
they believed the failure to secure
an opponent was significant of the
unwillingness of the power interests, who were asked to send a
speaker, to discuss the situation.

In a game that was marked by a
great deal of clever and crafty playing, the Johns Hopkins Varsity
twelve downed the Olympic Club
stickmen last Saturday afternoon at
Homewood field in the opening
game of the season.
Veterans Crafty

The veteran team, which represented the United States at Amsterdam in 1928 in the Olympic Games,
was in much better physical condition last Saturday than they were
last spring when they met the Varsity twelve in their opening game.
This improvement on the physical
side, did play a part in helping the
veterans to keep the issue in doubt
right up until the final whistle blew,
but it was their great experience in
the art of the game and their alertness, what was the main factor in
making it possible for them to keep
the Varsity on the run.

In addressing a banquet of the
Alumni Association of Washington
College, Governor Ritchie pointed
out that the "recognition of the
smaller colleges of Maryland as
integral parts of the higher educational system of the State is an ideal
policy to pursue in the future."
Governor Ritchie views with consternation the universities in other
sections of the country which have
enrollment of from 20,000 to 40,000
students; he finds it impossible to
conceive that proper or competent
instruction can be carried out in
such large institutions. A program
of decentralization, according to
Dr. Paul E. Titsworth, who also addressed the gathering would aid the
educational process, which he defined as one of "contact of the immature mind with the mature and
mellowed intellect."

EDITORIALS
TOO BAD
HE movement on foot to revive varsity baseball at Hopkins is a

Tworthy one, but one that is fore-doomed to failure. Baseball is an

excellent game to play and, while .lacking the speed of lacrosse, is an
interesting sport to watch, particularly if the spectators are conversant
with the intricacies of the game. The sports writers of the country,
in a recent poll, praised baseball as the game most fitted for college
men. They claimed that the game is fine exercise for all the muscles
of the body and that it does not exert the tremendous physical and
nervous strain upon the player that lacrosse and football do.
Nevertheless, we feel that the athletic authorities will never consent
to a baseball team at Hopkins. From their point of view, they are
right, for baseball is a game that requires a great deal of financial outlay without drawing large enough crowds to compensate for the expense involved.. Furthermore, the undergraduate body at Hopkins is
too small to furnish enough material for both good lacrosse and baseball teams. Even if there were enough material, the lure of the diamond would coax many men from the crease just as track now claims
men who are potential lacrosse stars. And the athletic authorities will
do nothing to dim the wonderful reputation which Hopkins has now
in lacrosse.
So the baseball enthusiasts must resign themselves to failure, worthy
as their cause is. It is a great pity that our athletic appropriation is
, . not large enough to increase the variety of teams representing Hopkins.

MORE CONGRATULATIONS
Hopkins students were given a big boost toward success
SIXTEEN
in their chosen profession when they were admitted to the Medical
School last week. These students can claim without fear of contradiction that their college years have been successful.
The start in life which the Hopkins Medical School gives its graduates is equalled by no other educational institution in the country. It
surpasses its nearest rival, the Harvard School of Law, in the universal
esteem with which it endows its graduates. A man is not made simply
because he has received his M. D. from Hopkins, but, other things
being equal, he has a great advantage over his fellows at the start.
Particularly so if he intends to practice in Baltimore or the vicinity.
The reputation of the Medical School works only one evil; it
overshadows the other departments of the University. Because the
Medical School is so well known, laymen throughout the country believe that all Hopkins men are students of medicine or are, at least,
pursuing a pre-medical course. However, all Hopkins men puff with
pride at the mention of the Medical School even though they must
constantly explain that there really are other departments to the University.
Once more we congratulate the students who have been admitted
to the Medical School with the wish that they take full advantage of
the opportunity offered them.

The California Daily Bruin carries an interesting clipping concerning a novelty at the University of
Nevada: "Not since the days of
forty-niners in Nevada has there
been such a revival of the red-blooded, old-fashioned pastime of growing whiskers as that to be witnessed
on the chins of the students of the
State University here. The occasion
for all the hirsute display is the renewal of the traditional "whiskerins" dance festival of the University of Nevada, with every instructor, professor and student present
and 'bearded like the paro.'"

The Carnegie Institute of Technology at Pittsburgh, will hold its
annual exhibition, during which all
departments of the various colleges
will be open for public inspection.
With the characteristic attention of
the present day to the field of aviation, the exhibition will be featured
by an air tunnel, where, under the
direction of Mr. Lane Johnson, various aeroplane tests and aeronautical experiments will be conducted.
In addition to the specialty, there
will be a series of tests of model
dams by the Materials and Hydraulic Research Laboratories department; an advertising exhibition,
a retreat parade by the R. 0. T. C.,
and an exhibition of an Italian village square made entirely by students will, according to figures
made at the last exhibition, attract
some 12,000 visitors. Additional features on the program will include
music recitals, plays, concerts, exhibitions by members of the varsity swimming team and displays of
the work of students in the various
departments.

Another once well-accepted tradition gone the way of all flesh: In
the spring a young man's fancy
does not turn to thoughts of love
—a compilation of statistics by the
faculty at the Pennsylvania State
College shows that at this season of
the year, contrary to general opinion as the morbid effects of spring

and takes a more interested part in
campus activities than at any other
period of the term.

In the College of Law at the
Ohio State University, excuses
claiming sickness as a reason for
absence will no longer be accepted
unless the student has suffered from
a "protracted illness." A student
who has "cut" more than 15 per
cent of his classes will be barred
from taking examination, and will
be failed automatically, as a part of
a program of attendance enforcement, announced by Dean Hershel
W. Arant. The ruling aims principally at "fake" excuses; "many excuses offered," asserted Dean Arant,
"are not for valid illness, yet we
cannot take time to investigate the
genuineness of every case." The 15
per cent privilege, the dean believes,
will allow the student ample leeway
for slight illnesses, absences due to
business of other reasons. Hereafter, every excuse will be required
to have the personal approval of the
dean.

ma de by Laurie D. Cox, a noted author on lacrosse, the University of

the All-American lacrosse team and
has also achieved second ranking
among lacrosse teams of the country. The two old-timers to gain this
distinction are Bill Evans in home,
and Emmet Loane, second defense.
Evans, who is still with the Maryland team was also the highest point
scorere of the country last year.

Last Saturday, Professor Albright, of the Department of Semetic Languages in Hopkins, addressed the Baltimore Quarterly
Meeting, in the Friends Meeting
Hall, on Charles Street. He spoke
on "Archaeological Explanation in
the Land of the Bible," and used
slides to show the interesting remains.

Plans are being made to professionalize the Federal prison service
by enlisting high-grade officers and
by establishing a system of professional training and promotion on
merit. In the belief that collegetrained men may be interested in
this type of work the leading colleges and universities in the country
are being circularized. Any undergraduate or graduate who wishes to
consider the possibility of entering
the service is requested to write the
Superintendent of Prisons, Department of Justice, Washington, D. C.
